The 1994 Division Bell tour started on this day, with a show in Miami, Florida, in the USA. In total, the tour performed to 5.5 million people in 68 cities. Timeline Photos

Another anniversary - today marks 20 years since the release of Pink Floyd's final album, The Division Bell. The band struggled to find a suitable title, considering things like Pow Wow and Down To Earth. Eventually, with the promise of a donation to his favourite charity The Environmental Investigation Agency, the writer Douglas Adams came up with The Division Bell as his suggested title, which the band liked. Timeline Photos

On this day four years ago, the UK's Royal Mail issued a set of ten stamps commemorating Classic Album Covers. Due to the dimensions of the stamps themselves, the decision was made that the most suitable Floyd cover to use would be The Division Bell. Here's the resulting stamp in all its glory: Timeline Photos
Marooned, from 1994's The Division Bell. The track won Best Rock Instrumental Performance at the 1995 Grammy Awards. Marooned
Keep Talking appears on The Division Bell, and was also the first single release from the album in the US. Pink Floyd - Keep Talking

With tonight's show at London's Earls Court in 1994 going ahead without any hitches (see yesterday's post), one of the tracks performed was High Hopes... Pink Floyd - High Hopes High Hopes is a song from the 1994 Pink Floyd album The Division Bell.
Marooned is taken from Pink Floyd's 1994 album, The Division Bell, and won a Grammy Award the following year. Pink Floyd - Marooned
An eye-catching ticket for today's show in Belgium: Timeline Photos
In 1981, the band played eight shows in Dortmund - here's the poster advertising them: Timeline Photos

The first of seven shows at the LA Memorial Sports Arena took place today in 1980, bringing Pink Floyd The Wall - with its stunning theatrical presentation, a landmark concert staging - to fans. Timeline Photos

To coincide with the release of Animals, the Floyd started their 1977 tour on this day. Here's the poster, featuring the portraits from Meddle rather than any of the then new album's imagery: Timeline Photos

Today in 1968, Pink Floyd appeared at the two-day Flight To Lowlands Paradise festival in Utrecht, The Netherlands. Jimi Hendrix was begged to appear, but couldn't be persuaded, and the Floyd took his place. Here's the colourful poster for that show. Timeline Photos
Soundchecking in 1977... Timeline Photos
December was a good month for Pink Floyd concerts - and here's a nicely designed poster for one of them: Zurich, 1972. Timeline Photos

The final show on the 1967 Jimi Hendrix Winter Tour took place on this day, and included Pink Floyd as one of the bands on the bill. This picture appeared in the programme, and shows the various performers. Can you spot the four members of Pink Floyd in the picture? Timeline Photos

The 1967 Jimi Hendrix Winter Tour was in full swing at this stage in that year. One of the support bands was Pink Floyd, given around 20 minutes in each of the two shows each day (a matinee concert, and an evening concert). Timeline Photos

An eight track vinyl promo was created for US radio use, around the time that Pink Floyd The Wall was released. The promo itself is hard to find these days, and here's the custom cover created for it... Timeline Photos

Out today in 1988 was the live album Delicate Sound of Thunder, recorded over five nights at the Nassau Coliseum on Long Island, New York in August 1988 and released on vinyl, cassette and CD. The cover image relates to the dual aspects of Pink Floyd's concerts - the sound (the birds flapping) and the light... Timeline Photos

In 1972, Pink Floyd performed a charity show at the Empire Pool (later the Wembley Arena, which still features an Olympic sized swimming pool under the flooring) raising money for three different charities... Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd concluded their 1994 World Tour with a set of concerts in October at London's Earls Court, with proceeds from each night going towards a range of charities selected by the band. This picture (photographer unknown) shows the striking frontage of the venue for the shows. Timeline Photos

A return to the Werchter Festival Ground for the band, having last played there in 1989, kicking off that year's European tour with a rousing version of Astronomy Domine. Were any of you there? Timeline Photos
In 1971, Pink Floyd appeared in Japan, performing a number of shows. Here's the band at a press conference: Timeline Photos

Another rescheduled August show, this took place on this day at Manchester City's Maine Road football ground, home to the club for eighty years and briefly used for staging concerts. The band travelled to the city from London, and back again, using the train, much to the surprise of fans doing the same thing! Timeline Photos

Today in 1967, Pink Floyd performed at the Two Red Shoes Ballroom in Elgin, Scotland. As this newspaper report shows, the band weren't terribly impressed with the stage, but potentially some of the audience weren't overly enamoured by the band's music either... Timeline Photos

With an audience on site of over 200,000, and an estimated worldwide audience of 100 million, courtesy of a live broadcast to more than 20 countries, Pink Floyd's 1989 concert in the lagoon in Venice proved an incredible spectacle... Timeline Photos
Here's the first of two Live 8 rehearsal pictures from June 2005... Timeline Photos
There were two notable posters for Pink Floyd's pair of concerts at the Chateau de Versailles in France, 28 years ago - this one was before the second night was added... Timeline Photos

Advance tickets for Pink Floyd's concert on this day in 1977 were $10.60, and on sale at various record stores and other outlets in the Chicago area. There was some suspicion generally over the number of tickets sold though for this show - officially 67,000, but the band hired a helicopter to take pictures of the crowd to do a head count, which gave a figure closer to 95,000... Timeline Photos
Twenty-eight years ago...were you at this show? Timeline Photos

Today in June 1981, Pink Floyd were half way through a run of five sold-out nights presenting The Wall at London's Earls Court. Due to the logistics of staging, and touring, the show, it was only performed 31 times, in just four cities - London, New York, Los Angeles and Dortmund. Timeline Photos
Twenty-two years ago today, Pink Floyd performed the second of two nights at New York's Yankee Stadium. Did you see the band during their extensive tour that year? Timeline Photos

Whilst it appeared at the time to be a bootleg, this US promo LP, issued to help promote the concerts taking place at the time (with the band playing in Maryland on this day), was entirely genuine and is much sought after now... Timeline Photos

A band always known for revolutionary live presentation, this poster for the Floyd's three nights in Philadelphia, 1994, promotes the quadrophonic sound and notes the band were "redefining the stadium spectacular". Timeline Photos
This golden poster advertises a couple of shows, including Pink Floyd's performance at London's UFO on June 1st, 1967... Timeline Photos
An embossed ticket was issued for the 1989 concert in Verona, Italy... Timeline Photos
http://www.pinkfloyd.com/vinyl Timeline Photos

In 1989, Pink Floyd started their European tour at the Festival Ground in Werchter, in Belgium. With a large tree in the middle of the audience area, it had a different feeling to many of the shows on the tour, and also caused problems during the set-up of the show, with one key element of the show getting caught up in the branches during the afternoon... Timeline Photos
A concert described as "space age relaxation for the climax of spring – electronic composition, colour and image projection, girls, and the Pink Floyd"...today in 1967. Timeline Photos
One of the best loved Pink Floyd concert posters - this one for the two nights in Oakland, 1977... Timeline Photos
A striking if slightly unusual image for a Pink Floyd concert poster... Timeline Photos

The beautiful, historic Carnegie Hall in New York was host to Pink Floyd on this day in 1972 (just six months after their last appearance there). The architecture and highly regarded acoustics would have made it a wonderful place to hear the band run through the early version of The Dark Side Of The Moon. Were any of you at the show? If so, what do you remember most strongly?

"Even the flying pig got soaked..." Today in 1988, Pink Floyd played the Florida Citrus Bowl in Orlando, Florida, but the weather was against them, with a heavy rain storm hitting the show – hard. Here's a local news report on the concert, and the weather conditions which tried (and failed) to dampen the audience's spirits: http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1988-05-02/lifestyle/0030440211_1_pink-floyd-circular-screen-floyd-music. Timeline Photos

On this day in 1968, Pink Floyd played the Piper Club in Rome, Italy – an unusual venue in that it was situated in a cave, with a long staircase to access it... here's a picture of the venue: Timeline Photos

On this day in 2000, Pink Floyd released Is There Anybody Out There - The Wall Live 1980-81. A number of different advertising posters were created, for different reasons and markets, and here's a lesser seen example: Timeline Photos
In March 1973, Pink Floyd were performing The Dark Side of the Moon to North American audiences, and on this day, did a midnight show in New York's Radio City Music Hall. Timeline Photos
As befitting the "underground" nature of the concerts, posters for UFO performances weren't hugely detailed... Timeline Photos

In the 1974 UK tour programme (repeated in the US for the 1975 dates), which was presented as a child's comic, the pages had various fictionalised stories about the Floyd. There was also a look at the various attributes, likes, and dislikes, of the band members. Clearly very much "tongue in cheek", not all the answers were to be taken entirely seriously - and neither is the ordering of the
sketches of each band member at the top of the page! Timeline Photos
In 1973, Pink Floyd performed in Madison, Wisconsin. Here's a local newspaper report from the morning after, describing the show as "overwhelming" and "exhausting"... Timeline Photos
Here's the striking 1988 poster for Pink Floyd's Tokyo concerts... Timeline Photos
There's something special about old concert tickets, particularly when they are as well designed as this example: Timeline Photos

At the start of the week, we talked about the first of the 1980 Wall concerts. On this day in 1981, the first of eight concerts in Dortmund took place. The tickets were particularly striking, with a cut-out, brick wall design, as you'll see from this example from the run of shows there... Timeline Photos
For the live performances of The Wall in 1980, potential attendees had to place their requests for tickets via mail order, as this advert details: Timeline Photos

Today in 1980, the first of The Wall concerts took place, which (understandably for such complex staging) didn't go without a hitch - during the show, some pyrotechnics set fire to some stage drapes, requiring the show to be temporarily halted while the flames were put out. Timeline Photos

Today, Pink Floyd engineer Andy Jackson releases his new album 73 Days at Sea, the follow-up to 2014's excellent Signal to Noise. For more information, visit http://andyjacksonmusic.com/ Timeline Photos

Today in 1977, Pink Floyd kicked off their In The Flesh World Tour, with the first of two shows in Dortmund. Curiously, the poster for the initial dates used a significantly earlier picture of the band... Timeline Photos
As a follow-up to 1975's Wish You Were Here, Animals came as a big surprise to many fans, although the 1974 tour did include early versions of Sheep and Dogs. Timeline Photos
This poster for an early Pink Floyd show gives a good indication to potential attendees of the visual nature of the band's performances... Timeline Photos

In 1972, Pink Floyd collaborated with Roland Petit for a ballet set to the band's music, with five performances held in Marseilles. Due to the success of those, in January 1973, there were eight further performances, which were held at the Palais des Sports de la Porte de Versailles in Paris. Timeline Photos

In 1968, Pink Floyd were amongst those on the bill for the Flight To Lowlands Paradise II concert, held at Margriethal-Jaarbeurs, in Utrecht, The Netherlands. The two-day event was delayed from November with the hopes that Jimi Hendrix would participate, but despite this delay Jimi didn't take part. Timeline Photos

In 1966, Pink Floyd performed the Art School Psychedelic Freak Out concert at Cambridge's College of Art and Technology, and here's the poster, showing how the original date of the gig changed (or was misprinted). Timeline Photos

The 1974 Winter Tour was heading toward its conclusion with a pair of shows at the Bristol Hippodrome on this day today/tomorrow. The tour programme was in the form of a children's comic, with the Floyd appearing separately in various stories. Here's the cover of the programme, a bargain at just 15p. Timeline Photos
In 1972, Pink Floyd performed at the Hallenstadion in Zurich, Switzerland. The poster advertising the show featured a drawing of the band with a rather windswept and cosmic feel... Timeline Photos

Today in 1967 saw the final pair of shows (a matinee and evening show) on the Jimi Hendrix Winter Tour, which included Pink Floyd in support. As they only had 20 minutes allocated to them, the set each night for the Floyd was Take Up Thy Stethoscope and Walk, and Interstellar Overdrive. Timeline Photos

On November 21st and 22nd 1970, Pink Floyd played at the Altes Casino in Montreux, Switzerland – the subject of Deep Purple's Smoke On The Water. Here's the poster for the event, which erroneously lists 'Sid' Barrett as still a member of the band. Timeline Photos
In 1988, the live album Delicate Sound of Thunder was released. The album was recorded during the Floyd's five nights at the Nassau Coliseum in New York three months' earlier. Timeline Photos

The second night of the Jimi Hendrix Winter Tour 1967 took place in Bournemouth on this day with a pair of shows. The tour, which included Pink Floyd alongside The Nice, The Move, Amen Corner, Eire Apparent and Outer Limits, all in support of Jimi's Experience, saw most venues enjoying a matinee and evening show. Timeline Photos
In November 1987, Pink Floyd were in the midst of touring. Here's one of the designs which appeared on the t-shirts available from the shows: Timeline Photos
As part of the band's 1971 Meddle US tour, Pink Floyd performed in Boston at the Music Hall. Here's the poster for the event: Timeline Photos
The Fillmore Auditorium in San Francisco saw Pink Floyd playing on this date in 1967. As the poster shows, they were sharing the billing with Procol Harum and HP Lovecraft. Timeline Photos

In 1994, Pink Floyd performed their final ever full length concert, with a show concluding a fifteen night run at London's Earls Court. All the profits from the fifteen concerts went to a selection of 13 charities picked by the band themselves, which included Amnesty International and Greenpeace. Timeline Photos

In 1969, Pink Floyd performed at the Amougies Festival in Belgium, which included Frank Zappa in the role as MC despite his very limited French. Zappa guested with a number of acts, including Pink Floyd, as this picture shows: Timeline Photos
Moonshine, washing line... Timeline Photos
In October 1968 Pink Floyd performed in France, and this rare shot captures them relaxing in the afternoon. Timeline Photos
This eye-catching poster for Pink Floyd's 1970 appearance in San Rafael, California, was impossible to miss! Timeline Photos
A scarce surviving ticket for the Floyd's 1973 show in Munich, Germany... Timeline Photos

Due to exceptional demand, a second concert at the Allianz Parque, Sao Paulo, Brazil, has been announced. This additional show, taking place on December 11th, will include seating in the stadium area in front of the stage, and tickets should be available now.

Seven years ago, David Gilmour released Live in Gdańsk, which was available in four different versions: you could have just the live album if you wished, or choose from the editions which included a DVD of the show, a surround mix of On An Island, and additional live tracks and replica concert memorabilia. Timeline Photos

The second of three days of the Rugby Bag Blues Festival took place today in 1969, with Pink Floyd playing alongside acts such as The Nice, King Crimson, and Free. Hells Angels policed the event, which was beset by bouts of very heavy rain. Timeline Photos

As part of the 2011 launch of Pink Floyd's Discovery, Experience, and Immersion editions of the back catalogue, as well as an inflatable pig once more patrolling the skies above London's Battersea Power Station, the Capitol Records building in Los Angeles was also topped by one. The antenna on the building's roof has a blinking light for aircraft; normally it spells out the word HOLLYWOOD in Morse Code, but for the occasion, it was changed to spell out PINKFLOYD... Timeline Photos

In 1988, Pink Floyd did a run of five nights at the Nassau Coliseum on Long Island, New York, recording the shows for the Delicate Sound of Thunder release. Here's the rare laserdisc version. Timeline Photos
From 1988, here's a scarce poster for the Oslo concert, originally scheduled for this day, but moved to August 2nd. Timeline Photos
One of Pink Floyd's more recognised, early concert posters. This is from the Sacramento shows in 1968... Timeline Photos
On this day in 1968, Pink Floyd played at San Francisco's Avalon Ballroom. The poster for the show didn't make it easy for possible attendees with the text being quite hard to read... Timeline Photos
http://smarturl.it/DGintntl Timeline Photos

Concert staging is often basic, more obvious when performers are working during daylight. 45 years ago, the Hyde Park Free Concert took place, and here's a shot of Pink Floyd during their set. Timeline Photos

30 years ago today, Live Aid took place in London and Philadelphia. The concert held on both continents was staged to raise funds for Ethiopian famine relief. Bryan Ferry was one of the performers in London, with a band including Jon Carin on keyboards, and David Gilmour on guitar... Timeline Photos
Not a bad line-up for £2.75... Timeline Photos

In 1989, Pink Floyd played the first of what quickly became six nights at the London Arena in the Docklands area, when the advertised four nights sold out. The first night was for charity, and the final show was - unusually - an afternoon show, to help with moving the production to The Netherlands for the concert following these London gigs. Timeline Photos

In 1988, Pink Floyd performed at the historic Place d'Armes at the Chateau de Versailles in France. To commemorate the show, a very limited edition, white vinyl Momentary Lapse was sold, with a special poster included within the package. Timeline Photos
Which three Pink Floyd/solo albums would you suggest to a Floyd novice to demonstrate the variety found within the band's music? Timeline Photos
On this day in 1989 Pink Floyd were in the midst of their Another Lapse tour, playing the second of a pair of concerts in Livorno, Italy. Here's the cover of the tour programme: Timeline Photos

In 1973, the Floyd played the first of two nights at London's Earls Court (a venue now being demolished for housing) in aid of the National Campaign for the Homeless, with all profits going to the charity Shelter. This poster shows them onstage during that concert. Timeline Photos

In 1967 Pink Floyd performed one of their key concerts: Games For May - Space Age Relaxation For The Climate Of Spring. Held at the Queen Elizabeth Hall in London, it was reportedly the first show to use speakers at the rear of the hall to give a quadraphonic, surround sound effect. The show included the band chopping wood on stage, a man dressed as an admiral giving out daffodils, and a bubble machine, the output of which staining the seats and carpets. Timeline Photos
Here's another poster from the 1988 tour, for the Sacramento and Oakland shows.  April was often a busy touring month for the Floyd. Timeline Photos

With a live career spanning decades, we suspect a number of you were fortunate enough to have seen Pink Floyd in concert. If you did, what show(s) did you see, and what do you remember most vividly or fondly? Timeline Photos
In 1968, Pink Floyd's French record label created this poster of the band, originals of which are hard to find now. Timeline Photos
The first night of Dortmund's 1981 Wall concerts took part on this day, as this poster advertising the event reveals. Timeline Photos

In 1968, during the short-lived five piece Pink Floyd era, a handful of concerts were performed around England. One of them, in Lewes, Sussex, is detailed on the Lewes Football Club website here: http://www.lewesfc.com/the-pink-floyd-floodlights/ under the title "Shine On You Crazy Floodlights". Alongside the recollections of that show are a couple of items the band signed on that day - a photo and the concert poster. These are two extremely rare items genuinely signed by all five, and with thanks to Lewes FC, here's the signed concert poster: Timeline Photos

In 1967, the band performed a concert billed as "Music in Colour by the Pink Floyd" at London's Commonwealth Institute. The concert poster, here, lacked the sort of colour that the audience would have enjoyed... Timeline Photos

In 1973, Pink Floyd performed the first of eight shows, over four different days, at the Palais des Sports de la Porte de Versailles, Paris France. This was for the soundtrack to the Pink Floyd Ballet, choreographed by the late Roland Petit. Timeline Photos
Pink Floyd producer Andy Jackson has also been busy on his own music, and his new album, Signal To Noise has just been released. More details here: http://andyjacksonmusic.com Timeline Photos

Today in 2006, David Gilmour performed the final show of his On An Island tour, where he played to an audience of 50,000 at the Gdansk Shipyard to celebrate the founding of the Solidarity trade union. The show featured "A Great Day For Freedom", the only show of the tour to include this 1994 Floyd song. The concert was released two years later in various configurations, including the live album and DVD. Timeline Photos
With a set including Interstellar Overdrive, Astronomy Domine and A Saucerful Of Secrets, Pink Floyd performed the first of two nights in Sacramento, California, today in 1968. Timeline Photos

Evolve Devolve, the Italian promoters of The Pink Floyd Exhibition, have announced today that the Exhibition, due to start on 19 September 2014 in Milan, has had to be postponed due to production delays. Building the complex Exhibition to the required specification has made it impossible to make the opening date.   

Ticket sales for the Exhibition are currently suspended. Existing ticket purchases will remain valid once the new exhibition dates are announced or can be refunded at point of purchase.

Apologies for any inconvenience this might cause.

Today in 1971, the Floyd played the second of two nights at Hakone Aphrodite 71, Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park, Hakone, Japan as part of their first tour of that country. The guide to the venue was in cartoon style... Timeline Photos

Sharing the bill with the likes of The Animals, The Crazy World Of Arthur Brown, Tomorrow, and The Nervous System Apostolic Intervention, Pink Floyd performed at the International Love-In Festival at London's Alexandra Palace in 1967... Timeline Photos

Today in 1967, Pink Floyd were in the midst of a short tour of Scotland. They performed at the Two Red Shoes Ballroom in Elgin, and this advert for the show promises a "group that brings its own lighting to set the scene oscilating and vibrating with Way Out Sets"... Timeline Photos

Today marks the 25th anniversary of Pink Floyd's concert in Venice. The 1989 concert, on the Canal di San Marco, was performed on a floating stage. It was broadcast live on TV to over 20 countries with an estimated audience of almost 100 million. Did you watch this show, in Venice or at home? Timeline Photos
http://smarturl.it/pfsummercampaign Timeline Photos

Today in 1988, Pink Floyd performed the first of two nights at the Chateau de Versailles, in France. A spectacular show, it featured a firework display over the Chateau itself at the conclusion of the concert. There was a French-only special tour edition of A Momentary Lapse of Reason pressed on white vinyl with a Versailles 1988 poster. 

Here’s the concert poster: Timeline Photos

Today in 1977, Pink Floyd performed at Chicago’s Soldier Field. The poster shows the name of the tour that year - In The Flesh - which Roger Waters used in the project that was to follow: The Wall. Timeline Photos
#TDB20 Timeline Photos

Today in 1969, Pink Floyd performed at the Brighton Dome along with “their Azimuth Co-ordinator” which drove their quadrophonic surround effects during the show. The venue, once the stables for the adjacent Royal Pavilion, proved a favourite on the south coast for the band, who performed there a few times, most notably at the (ill-fated) start of the 1972 tour of The Dark Side of the Moon where the first public performance of the work only got as far as the start of Money… Timeline Photos
Pink Floyd were in the middle of a five night run at Bol Saja Sportivnaja Arena, Lushniki, in Moscow, Russia, on this day in 1989. Here’s one of the posters created for these shows: Timeline Photos
For the 1969 tour, the programme included some elements drawn by Nick Mason, akin to his later work on the Relics cover. This spread shows the band's tour plans, it seems. Timeline Photos

The 1989 European tour was in full swing by this stage in May - on this day that year, they performed the second of two nights in Livorno, Italy. The tour programme (as well as the concert posters and tickets) all had variations on the theme of the "lightbulb man". Timeline Photos

In a wonderfully rural setting, Pink Floyd's 1989 tour started in Werchter, Belgium. Taking the place of the plane was a flying bed for "On The Run". In the venue was a large tree in the audience area, and in the afternoon before the show, this initially caused problems as the bed - whilst being winched back ready for its flight - got caught up in branches. Timeline Photos

One of Pink Floyd's key 1967 shows took place today. The Games For May concert at the Queen Elizabeth Hall included the first quadraphonic sound system used in a live setting, a man dressed as an admiral giving out daffodils, the band chopping wood on stage, and bubbles generated from a machine during the show (which ended up staining all the furniture in the hall - resulting in a ban for the group from this venue). This picture shows the band during rehearsals. Timeline Photos

This striking poster promoted a show at the Terrace Ballroom in Salt Lake City, in 1970. We presume that the artist hadn't heard their music prior to designing the poster, perhaps being more suited to a heavy rock band. Timeline Photos

Even at $12.50, this ticket to see Pink Floyd in the Los Angeles area in 1977 on their In The Flesh tour does seem a bargain, but clearly an incentive of $3 off was felt in order for those who bought their ticket early... Timeline Photos

A band that makes heavenly music? Maybe that was the inspiration behind the poster for the Floyd's show today in 1972 at the John F Kennedy Center for Performing Arts, in Washington DC. Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd appeared at Mothers Club in Birmingham, England today in 1969, and BBC Radio 1 DJ John Peel said that the show sounded "like dying galaxies lost in sheer corridors of time and space". Parts of the show were used on the Ummagumma live album, which, if your country has it, can be heard on Spotify: http://open.spotify.com/album/55MYyc2jD5T1YgOUpuwEbf

More Furious Madness from the Massed Gadgets of Auximenes took place on this day in 1969 at the Royal Festival Hall in London, with Pink Floyd enhancing their The Man and The Journey song suites with the Azimuth Co-ordinator, a joystick operated quadraphonic sound system operated by Richard Wright from the stage. The Man and The Journey blended new songs along older ones (albeit under new titles) whilst things like a table being made took place on stage so that the band could be served tea! Timeline Photos
This slightly bizarre poster advertised the 1994 San Antonio concert - particularly odd as the pig used in the concerts was most definitely male... Timeline Photos

In 2000, official recordings of the original Wall concerts were released as Is There Anybody Out There? The start of the concert featured the surrogate band wearing "lifemasks" of Roger, David, Richard and Nick, and the packaging of this release included pictures of these rather eerie masks. Timeline Photos

Our final concert poster - for now. This one isn't quite so easy on the eye. It's advertising Reading University's RagBall in 1969, with the Floyd supported by the Pretty Things, and also offered folk singing, coffee and snacks, and noted that the event was "dress optional"! Timeline Photos

Earlier this week, we talked about the Floyd's 1988 concerts in Japan. This time of year was obviously good for them to visit that country, as in 1972, they were performing there too - as this poster shows. Timeline Photos
At this stage in 1988, Pink Floyd were in the midst of the Japanese leg of their world tour. This rather nice poster was created for that country's concerts. Timeline Photos
The 1988 tour arrived in Tokyo, Japan, for the first of two nights, on this day. Here's the poster advertising the dates: Timeline Photos
In 1995, Pink Floyd's Marooned won a Grammy Award at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Timeline Photos
The 1971 European tour was in full swing by this point in February, and this evening saw a show taking place in Offenbach, Germany. Timeline Photos

One of the more interesting posters from 1971 is for the Floyd's show in Farnborough, Hampshire. It features The Mekon, a character in the Dan Dare comic strip. Which Pink Floyd song mentions Dan Dare? Timeline Photos
This rare poster advertises an early 1967 concert Pink Floyd held in Brighton, on the south coast of England. Timeline Photos

The Wall tour of 1980 started on this day at the Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena. The first night didn't go as smoothly as planned - some pyrotechnics set fire to some curtains, forcing the band to temporarily halt the show. Timeline Photos
The Floyd performed the first of eight shows, over four days, with the Roland Petit Ballet in Paris, back in 1973... Timeline Photos
"I want to tell you a story..." Timeline Photos
Quite a line-up...looks like it would have been well worth the £1 for the ticket. Timeline Photos

Today in 1967, the final night of the Jimi Hendrix UK Winter Tour took place, with the customary pair of shows (a matinee, and a more standard evening show). For the concerts, Pink Floyd were low on the bill and had less than 20 minutes, so their set consisted of Pick Up Thy Stethoscope And Walk, and Interstellar Overdrive. Timeline Photos

In 2000, Roger Waters released his In The Flesh live album. Encapsulating his tour of the same name that year, which included Jon Carin, Andy Fairweather-Low and Snowy White in the band, the 2-disc album came from various shows in the US. A DVD with the same title came from one of these shows. You can hear the album on Spotify: http://open.spotify.com/album/2nLlxARvKxRTywW7kS6sB7 Timeline Photos
Mr Sound... Timeline Photos

Tonight in 1967 the Jimi Hendrix Winter Tour was in full swing, with Pink Floyd as one of Jimi's support bands. For the tour programme, they got the performers all together for a picture. Can you spot Roger, Syd, Nick and Richard in the midst of the others? Timeline Photos
Pink Floyd made their first New York appearance at the Cheetah Club in 1967. Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd released their double album Ummagumma on this day in 1969. The back cover had a shot of the band's touring equipment laid out, and here's an alternate shot from that photographic session: Timeline Photos

RSVP now for the event: http://g.co/standup2013. This picture shows Roger during rehearsals for this year's show. Timeline Photos

The annual Stand Up For Heroes event, presented by the Bob Woodruff Foundation and the New York Comedy Festival, aims to help post 9/11 service members and their families thrive long after they return home. Roger Waters' performance, with a band comprised of nearly two dozen musicians and singers - all of whom are wounded active service members or veterans representing all branches of the US armed forces including the Musicorps Wounded Warrior band from Walter Reed hospital - will be available November 6th via a live webcast featuring a Google+ Hangout. RSVP now for the event: http://g.co/standup2013. This picture shows Roger during last year's show. Timeline Photos

This day in 1994, Pink Floyd performed the last of fifteen nights at London's Earls Court. This turned out to be the final full-length Pink Floyd concert, with the band not performing together again until 2005's Live8, where Roger Waters rejoined them. Timeline Photos
The last of our 'anniversary' concert posters (for now) as we remember the 1971 concert at San Diego's Community Concourse. Tickets for the show were priced at $3, $3.50 and $4. Timeline Photos

The second of our 'anniversary' posters, was for Pink Floyd's appearance at the launch event for the International Times newspaper. The show took place at London's Roundhouse in 1966, and concert-goers were urged to bring their own "poison, flowers & gass filled balloons" to the show. Timeline Photos
We have three interesting early Pink Floyd posters for you this week. The first is from 1966, and is for one of their formative shows at the All Saints Hall in London's Powis Gardens. Timeline Photos

Today in 1987, Pink Floyd performed at the Rosemont Horizon, in Chicago, as the eleventh show on the Momentary Lapse tour that year. Those initial shows all started with Echoes, but this show in Chicago saw the final performance of the track, with Shine On taking over as opener for all subsequent shows. The tour programme, shown here, featured a gatefold cover with the 'beds on the beach' imagery. Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd played its last "college show" in the US at George Washington University's Lisner Auditorium in Washington DC in the autumn of 1971. While the band may have physically left the university scene, their music and their legend never did; their presence remain as strong as ever on campuses everywhere today, with Pink Floyd memorabilia adorning dorm rooms worldwide. The UFO Festival was held today/tomorrow in 1967 at London's Roundhouse. Pink Floyd appeared over both days, supported by Arthur Brown on the 1st, and The Move on the 2nd… Timeline Photos
The third of our August 1968 US posters for you - this time, it was for the first of two nights at The Bank, in Torrance, CA. Timeline Photos

In 1969, Pink Floyd performed at the 9th National Jazz, Pop, Ballads & Blues Festival in Plumpton, Sussex (a late change of venue). With their friends Soft Machine supporting, the band didn't stick to the genres in the festival's title, performing The Journey song suite along with Set The Controls, Cymbaline and Interstellar Overdrive. Unfortunately, power issues throughout the acts that evening meant that many of the audience had fallen asleep by the time Pink Floyd arrived on stage... Timeline Photos

1968 saw some very eye-catching posters for Pink Floyd concerts. This one was created for the Avalon Ballroom concert on this day, and with its complex font, was sure to have given San Francisco residents a hard time deciphering it! Timeline Photos
As part of their 1994 European tour, Pink Floyd played the second of two nights at the historic Chateau de Chantilly, in France, on this day. Here's the poster advertising the show: Timeline Photos
In 1970, Pink Floyd played in Aachen, West Germany, at the 1st Open Air Pop Festival, alongside other bands such as Deep Purple, Traffic and Golden Earring. Timeline Photos

Today in 1977, Pink Floyd played their infamous concert in Montreal which concluded their In The Flesh tour - and gave Roger the inspiration he needed for The Wall. Here's the much loved poster: Timeline Photos

With hot dogs and "soft ultra violet lighting" promised, along with the likes of Pink Floyd, Jimi Hendrix, Cream and The Move on the bill, this show being held in the small market town of Spalding, Lincolnshire, on this day in 1967 sounded well worth the £1 entrance fee... Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd appeared at Mothers Club in Birmingham, England today in 1969, and parts of the show were used on the Ummagumma live album. BBC Radio 1 DJ John Peel said that the show sounded "like dying galaxies lost in sheer corridors of time and space". Here's a rare surviving poster from the show: Timeline Photos
www.pinkfloyd.com #DarkSide40 Timeline Photos

In 1977, Pink Floyd toured their new album, Animals, although as this ticket for the Antwerp show on February 20th shows, they were also celebrating Wish You Were Here which came out two years earlier. Timeline Photos

Today in 1980, Pink Floyd started the quite limited tour of The Wall, with a night at the Los Angeles Sports Arena, affected by the small matter of a stage curtain catching fire due to some errant pyrotechnics... Timeline Photos

In 1979, Pink Floyd released the double album of The Wall. Spawning a revolutionary stage show (updated for Roger's 2010-2013 The Wall Live tour) and a film, it was a major project for the band. What's your favourite aspect of The Wall? Timeline Photos

On this day in 1974, Pink Floyd played the final show of four at the Empire Pool in Wembley, London. Included in the tour programme was a caricature of the band drawn by Gerald Scarfe, along with cartoon strips of the band members in various fantasy roles, and lyrics for their new songs Raving And Drooling and Gotta Be Crazy. Timeline Photos

A personal message from Roger

Last Thursday night at The Beacon Theater in NYC, I took part in an evening called, Stand Up For Heroes. 

This event is six years old, is put on by The Bob Woodruff Foundation and the New York Comedy Festival which raises money to help wounded veterans. 

I was privileged to perform with some of the wounded. A great bunch of young men (Will, Eric, Brandon, Josh, Nathan, Erik (soon to be Major Erik Johnson), Eddie, Daniel, Rex, Lander and Tim, to all of whom I extend my love and heartfelt thanks. So here's some of it.............. Victims of war, no matter who they are, or where they're from, are all to often forgotten, I support all who reach out to help them.
Thanks also to GE Smith, Jeff Kazee, Abe Fogle, Sergeant Jon Joyce, Arthur Bloom and Greg Loman.
Love 
Roger

Pink Floyd performed at the Music Hall in Boston today in 1971. Amongst the tracks performed that night were The Embryo, Set The Controls, and Fat Old Sun. Timeline Photos
In 1969, Pink Floyd released Ummagumma, a double album with one disc of live recordings, and one disc which featured each member of the band performing their own solo compositions. Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd's final run of concerts on the 1994 tour started on this day, at London's Earls Court running until October 29th, with proceeds from the concerts going to a selection of charities. The opening night show at Earls Court was shortlived, though, after a section of seating collapsed. No-one was seriously injured, although eight people were taken to hospital for treatment. This poster advertises the first of the shows to be announced. Timeline Photos
Pink Floyd performed a pair of shows at the Fillmore East, New York City, this day in 1970, performing tracks such as Fat Old Sun, A Saucerful of Secrets, and Astronomy Domine. Timeline Photos

In the month of September 1967, Pink Floyd took the opportunity during a break in concerts to visit a funfair at the Tivoli Gardens in Copenhagen, and practiced their shooting skills... Timeline Photos
On this day, Pink Floyd played the second of two nights at the then new venue The Bank in Torrance, California, which also marked the end of their 1968 US tour. Timeline Photos

Today in 2006, a pair of signed Pink Floyd giant eyeballs, one of only ten pairs, was auctioned on eBay in aid of the UK's homelessness charity Crisis (http://www.crisis.org.uk), of which David Gilmour was made a vice president back in 2003. David said: "The eBay auction will not only raise much needed funds for the charity, but will also raise awareness of the plight of the homeless at a time of year when they are most vulnerable".

The eyeballs, approximately six feet high, were signed by David, Richard Wright and Nick Mason, along with designer Storm Thorgerson. They were autographed at the July press launch in London of the PULSE double DVD. They sold for £16,500. Timeline Photos

This morning, Roger Waters and Nick Mason unveiled this commemorative plaque which has been installed onto the front of the University of Westminster (formerly known as the Regent Street Polytechnic) in London. It was whilst studying there that Roger, Nick and Richard Wright met, later leading to the forming of Pink Floyd. Photos from Pink Floyd's post

Their Front Row programme, which airs at 7:15pm BST, includes the interview - for those unable to hear it live, the show will be available in full on demand after broadcast. On this day in 2007, London's Barbican was the venue for Madcap's Last Laugh, a tribute event to the late Syd Barrett. with profits from the show donated to the mental health charity SANE. Visitors to London between now and the end of the year will find, in various locations, more than fifty specially designed statues of the character Paddington Bear - including one designed by Nick Mason which uses Wish You Were Here as its inspiration (with his suitcase having various backstage passes affixed), and can be found at the O2 Arena. The bears form The Paddington Trail, a fundraising effort to benefit the NSPCC (National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children) and children's charity Action Medical Research for whom Paddington Bear has been the official mascot for over 35 years.

There will be an auction for the statues and some of the more collectable items. It is hoped that The Paddington Trail and associated activities will raise over £500,000.
http://www.nspcc.org.uk/fighting-for-childhood/news-opinion/join-paddington-trail/?affId=1991357 Timeline Photos

A message from Roger Waters: Roger Waters A note from Roger:
Check out the CNN site http://heroes.cnn.com. It mentions my friend Arthur Bloom, the leader of Musicorps at Walter Reed Hospital, who has been nominated as Top Hero of 2014. I have worked with Arthur and many amazing vet musicians over the last few years. They are my brothers, I love them. If Arthur wins this CNN thing the vet music program will get $100,000. Please vote over the next days to register your support.

Arthur is one of ten nominees, I am sure the other nine are all very worthy, so I apologize for declaring my support for my particular brothers without due debate. The fact is we must all give our love and support to our brothers and sisters wherever and whenever we can.

Love
Roger

Potsdamer Platz in Berlin on this day, 1990, saw a huge performance of The Wall, performed by Roger Waters and his band, along with guests such as Van Morrison, Joni Mitchell, Bryan Adams and The Scorpions. Pink Floyd can confirm that they are releasing a new album "The Endless River" in October 2014. It is an album of mainly ambient and instrumental music based on the 1993/4 Division Bell sessions which feature David Gilmour, Nick Mason and Richard Wright. The album is produced by David Gilmour with Phil Manzanera, Youth and recording engineer Andy Jackson. Work is still in progress, but more details to come at the end of the Summer.

War Child is working with renowned British artist Tim Wakefield on a project called "Soundwaves" to celebrate and promote the work of iconic musicians. Tim has ten prints of the "Careful With That Axe, Eugene" soundwave image shown here, signed by Nick Mason, and is selling them online in aid of War Child's Children of Syria Appeal. This aims to raise funds for a new project with Syrian children outside of the refugee camps, where thousands of children remain inaccessible to services or too hidden to receive help. All donations to War Child's appeal will be matched pound-for-pound by the UK Government. Also included in this online sale are 19 other pieces of Soundwaves art inspired by the music of Queen, Brian Wilson, Eric Clapton and many more. The sale will run through to January 31st, 2014, and can be found at http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/soundwaves-art. Timeline Photos

Quote of the day:

On the band's lack of special stage clothing: "We are convinced that dressing for a show doesn't help the music we perform. The images and the lights help you to perceive the music. The public watches the images on the screen and doesn't have time to divert their attention to our dress..."
Nick Mason, Ciao 2001, May 1975

Quote of the day:

“We are simply a pop group. But because we use light and colour in our act, a lot of people seem to imagine that we are trying to put across some message with nasty, evil undertones.” 
Roger Waters, New Musical Express, July 1967.

On this day in 2005, Roger Waters released Ça Ira, an opera in three parts about the French Revolution. The libretto was co-written by Etienne and Nadine Roda-Gil, who approached Roger, asking him to set their work to music. Since its release it has had regular performances, often with full dramatic staging to bring the story more to life. Here's Roger talking about it:

Rockarchive, the rock photography collective and gallery network, have announced that Nick Mason will be holding a signing at their pop-up gallery in Monmouth St, WC2 on Thursday 30th May, between 5 and 6pm.

Nick will be visiting the Rockarchive pop-up shop to sign an edition of 50 exclusive photographic prints of himself, made specially for the occasion and available at a reduced price of £100 for the night only. Pink Floyd fans are also invited to bring along one item of personal Pink Floyd memorabilia that they wish to be autographed. On display will also be an extensive collection of Pink Floyd prints displayed in the gallery, plus there will be the chance to enter a raffle to win a signed pair of Nick’s drum sticks.

All prints displayed at the Rockarchive Pop-up Gallery are being sold at a 20% discount for the evening.

Address is: Rockarchive Pop Up Gallery, 46 Monmouth Street, Seven Dials, London WC2H 9EP. The gallery is open every day from 11am – 7pm until Monday 3rd June 2013.

Rockarchive's online site is at www.rockarchive.com. Timeline Photos

A Personal Statement from Roger Waters

"Tribunal Epilogue"
The great Jewish-American writer, professor, human rights activist, Nobel Laureate, and holocaust survivor, Elie Wiesel, the author of 'Night', famously wrote:
"..TO REMAIN SILENT AND INDIFFERENT IS THE GREATEST SIN OF ALL."
How right he was, and is. It is with great respect for Mr Wiesel and also for Bertrand Russell, the British philosopher and tireless advocate for human rights, who set up the first Russell Tribunal back in 1966 to protest the Vietnam war, that I presume to address these remarks to you, today.

Love
Roger

Watch as the largest Wall staging of the entire tour to date is built. The official Roger Waters The Wall Facebook page will be posting pictures throughout the day leading up to the show in Quebec City this Saturday. Tickets still available -http://bit.ly/rwquebec Timeline Photos

ROGER WATERS - THE WALL

THE PLAINS OF ABRAHAM – QUEBEC CITY

SATURDAY JULY 21st, 2012

An historic performance of ‘Roger Waters – The Wall’ will take place in Québec City on Saturday July 21st. This final date of the 2012 tour will feature the largest wall ever built.

Roger Waters says: “I’ve always loved playing in Québec. The Québécois are a very passionate and musical people and we’ll be playing on the Fields of Abraham. This is going to be completely unlike any of The Wall shows we’ve done anywhere else in the world.“

A limited number of priority tickets (wristbands) will be available in advance of the public sale for fans who register on RogerWaters.com between 9:00am on Wednesday May 23rd and 9pm Thursday May 31st.

Fans who have purchased a pass for this year’s Festival d’été de Québec can also get priority booking by registering online at www.infofestival.com during the same time period.

General public sales will commence on June 5th at www.infofestival.com

Many happy returns to hugely respected cartoonist and illustrator Gerald Scarfe, who celebrates his birthday today. Today is your last chance to submit a question for Gerald Scarfe. Please post it here as a comment on this thread, and all submitted questions this week will then be collated for Gerald to answer a selection of.

Gerald Scarfe is best known in the world of Floyd for his work on The Wall, but he has been involved with the band since 1974. UK-based Planet Rock Radio are broadcasting a one-hour special, 'Building The Wall', at 7pm GMT this Saturday, February 25th. Based on exclusive interviews with Planet Rock DJs from the last six months, it covers the whole of 'The Wall' from conception, to recording the original album and staging the shows, right up to Roger Waters' current tour. It includes interviews with Roger Waters, Nick Mason, Snowy White and Gerald Scarfe.

Planet Rock Radio is available on DAB in the UK or globally via planetrock.com Home

During his 2006 The Dark Side of the Moon tour, Roger Waters performed at the Kindl-Buhne, Wuhlheide, on the outskirts of Berlin. In a moment of perfect timing, as he performed the closing part of the album (Brain Damage and Eclipse) the moon was spotted in perfect position just above the stage, displaying its dark side... This date saw three commemorative editions of The Dark Side of the Moon released - in 1993, the 20th anniversary package, and in 2003, the 30th anniversary Super Audio CD and special vinyl edition. Timeline Photos

In 1973, Pink Floyd's The Dark Side of the Moon was released. A rough version of the track Brain Damage was written around the time of Meddle and was actually known as "The Dark Side of the Moon". For the 40th anniversary of the album, a collage was made of various alternate takes on the iconic prism image. Timeline Photos

The 1977 In The Flesh European tour, featuring Animals, was in full swing by this stage in March, and on this day they performed at Wembley's Empire Pool (later renamed Wembley Arena). A special edition of The Dark Side of the Moon was put together at the end of that year for the Japanese market, and included this shot of the band live as the cover. Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd started the first of a four-night run at London's Rainbow Theatre (which is now a Brazilian Pentecostal church), on this day in 1972. It was the premiere to the press of the then work-in-progress suite, The Dark Side of the Moon. Timeline Photos

This day in 1972 saw the first attempt to perform The Dark Side of the Moon live. The concert, at the Brighton Dome on the south coast of England, was beset by what Roger Waters called "severe mechanical and electric horror". This resulted in Dark Side being scrapped during Money and some older tracks being hastily brought into the setlist. This picture was taken backstage at the Dome in 1972 by Jill Furmanovsky. Timeline Photos

Ian Emes, who created the celebrated 'flying clocks' sequence in Time for the Dark Side Of The Moon concert screen films, has launched his own exhibition in London, presented as an "immersive installation". Emes also created the 'French Windows' animation based on One Of These Days, and was an advisor on The Wall film. Staged at the Unit 24 Gallery, 20 Great Guildford Street, London SE1 0FD, the exhibition runs until March 28, and is free. More info here: http://unit24.info Timeline Photos

Dark Side Of The Moon - A Photographic Exhibition marks the 40th anniversary of Pink Floyd's first attempted public performance of this album on January 20th 1972 at the Brighton Dome. The exhibition runs from January 20th to March 20th, 2012, at the Founders Room at the Dome, between 10am - 5pm, Tuesday through to Sunday, each week. Admission is free. Photographer Jill Furmanovsky spent considerable time on the road with the band that year, and the exhibition will display a range of her pictures, along with other rare and intimate images by Storm Thorgerson, Colin Prime and Tony Collins.
On the opening evening, there will be a Q&A with Jill, again being hosted in the Founders Room in the Dome. This starts at 7pm, and is also free: Brighton Dome - Dark Side of the Moon Brighton Tickets Celebrating the 40th anniversary of Pink Floyds first performance of this seminal album, which took place on 20th January 1972 at the Brighton Dome. The first International album charts have started to come in, and, in addition to topping the UK Album chart, David Gilmour's Rattle That Lock has debuted at Number One in a further six countries with more to come. The album is now Number One in the UK and Italy (following On An Island's chart-topping performance in both countries), France, Sweden, Norway, Belgium – in all three region charts – and New Zealand. 

David said: "It's thrilling to get a No. 1 album. We all want to hit the top spot, however long we've been at it; I'm delighted. I owe a debt of thanks to Polly Samson, for writing lyrics on four Number 1 albums: The Division Bell; On An Island; The Endless River; and now Rattle That Lock, and also to Phil Manzanera, my co-producer on the last three albums".

First week UK sales on vinyl of The Endless River were the highest of any LP released since 1997, making it the fastest-selling vinyl album this century, according to official UK Charts data.
 
The BPI, the trade body which represents the UK’s record labels, has just announced that annual sales of vinyl albums have exceeded the 1m mark for the first time since the Britpop era of the 1990s, according to Official Charts data released today. The Endless River is at Number 2 in the current Official Vinyl Chart behind the David Bowie 'Best Of', Nothing Has Changed. Timeline Photos
